channel.title: Last Day - NEW & UPDATE
channel.description: All NEW and UPDATE articles from the last day with enhanced metadata

item.title: NEW: ShinyHunters Hits Salesforce Again, Breaching Customers via Gainsight App
item.description:
Headline: ShinyHunters Hits Salesforce Again, Breaching Customers via Gainsight App

Summary:
Salesforce has disclosed a significant data breach affecting its customers, stemming from a compromised connection with the Gainsight customer success application. The notorious cybercrime group ShinyHunters, also tracked as UNC6240, has claimed responsibility for the attack, stating they exploited OAuth tokens to gain unauthorized access to approximately 285 additional Salesforce instances. In response, Salesforce has revoked credentials and removed the Gainsight apps from its AppExchange. The incident highlights the growing risk of supply chain attacks targeting trusted third-party SaaS integrations to pivot into major enterprise environments.

Severity: High

Categories: Supply Chain Attack, Data Breach, Threat Actor

Article Type: NewsArticle

Reading Time: 6 minutes

Meta Description: Salesforce discloses a major data breach affecting customers after the ShinyHunters group compromised the third-party Gainsight app, exploiting OAuth tokens to gain unauthorized access. Learn about the attack and mitigation steps.

Article Slug: shinyhunters-implicated-in-salesforce-data-breach-via-gainsight-app

Published Date: Fri, 21 Nov 2025 00:00:00 GMT

Created Date: Fri, 21 Nov 2025 15:00:00 GMT

Updated Date: Fri, 21 Nov 2025 15:00:00 GMT

Read Full Article →

item.title: NEW: SEC Abandons Landmark Lawsuit Against SolarWinds and its CISO
item.description:
Headline: SEC Abandons Landmark Lawsuit Against SolarWinds and its CISO

Summary:
In a surprising move, the U.S. Securities and Exchange Commission (SEC) has voluntarily dismissed its civil enforcement action against SolarWinds and its CISO, Timothy G. Brown. The lawsuit, filed in October 2023, had accused the company and Brown of misleading investors about their cybersecurity posture before the 2020 SUNBURST supply chain attack. The dismissal is seen as a major victory for the cybersecurity community, which had feared the case would set a dangerous precedent for holding security executives personally liable for breaches and create a chilling effect on transparency.

Severity: Informational

Categories: Policy and Compliance, Regulatory, Cyberattack

Article Type: NewsArticle

Reading Time: 5 minutes

Meta Description: The U.S. SEC has dropped its high-profile lawsuit against SolarWinds and its CISO, Timothy G. Brown, which alleged fraud related to the SUNBURST supply chain attack. This marks a significant moment for CISO liability and cybersecurity regulation.

Article Slug: sec-dismisses-lawsuit-against-solarwinds-and-ciso-timothy-brown

Published Date: Fri, 21 Nov 2025 00:00:00 GMT

Created Date: Fri, 21 Nov 2025 15:00:00 GMT

Updated Date: Fri, 21 Nov 2025 15:00:00 GMT

Read Full Article →

item.title: NEW: INC Ransomware Claims Breach of Burj Khalifa Fire-Safety Provider NAFFCO
item.description:
Headline: INC Ransomware Claims Breach of Burj Khalifa Fire-Safety Provider NAFFCO

Summary:
The INC ransomware group has claimed responsibility for a major cyberattack against NAFFCO, a Dubai-based fire-safety engineering firm known for its work on iconic structures like the Burj Khalifa. The threat actors posted on their dark web leak site that they exfiltrated 1 terabyte of sensitive data, including corporate contracts, financial records, and employee PII. To substantiate their claims, the group published 47 screenshots of the allegedly stolen files. NAFFCO, which reports $4.4 billion in annual revenue, has not yet commented on the incident.

Severity: High

Categories: Ransomware, Data Breach, Threat Actor

Article Type: NewsArticle

Reading Time: 5 minutes

Meta Description: The INC ransomware group has claimed a major cyberattack on NAFFCO, a Dubai-based fire-safety provider for the Burj Khalifa, alleging the theft of 1TB of sensitive corporate data.

Article Slug: inc-ransomware-claims-attack-on-burj-khalifa-fire-safety-provider-naffco

Published Date: Fri, 21 Nov 2025 00:00:00 GMT

Created Date: Fri, 21 Nov 2025 15:00:00 GMT

Updated Date: Fri, 21 Nov 2025 15:00:00 GMT

Read Full Article →

item.title: NEW: 'Scattered Spider' Suspects Plead Not Guilty in TfL Cyberattack Case
item.description:
Headline: 'Scattered Spider' Suspects Plead Not Guilty in TfL Cyberattack Case

Summary:
Two British teenagers, Thalha Jubair (19) and Owen Flowers (18), have pleaded not guilty to charges related to a major 2024 cyberattack on Transport for London (TfL). UK law enforcement believes the pair are members of the notorious 'Scattered Spider' hacking collective. The attack caused millions in losses and compromised customer data. Flowers also faces charges for attacks on U.S. healthcare organizations SSM Health and Sutter Health. The case highlights the severe legal consequences facing alleged members of this prolific cybercrime group.

Severity: Medium

Categories: Threat Actor, Cyberattack, Policy and Compliance

Article Type: NewsArticle

Reading Time: 5 minutes

Meta Description: Two suspected members of the Scattered Spider hacking group, Thalha Jubair and Owen Flowers, plead not guilty in London court to charges related to the 2024 Transport for London (TfL) cyberattack.

Article Slug: scattered-spider-suspects-plead-not-guilty-in-transport-for-london-hack

Published Date: Fri, 21 Nov 2025 00:00:00 GMT

Created Date: Fri, 21 Nov 2025 15:00:00 GMT

Updated Date: Fri, 21 Nov 2025 15:00:00 GMT

Read Full Article →

item.title: NEW: SANS Report: OT/ICS Cyber Incidents Rising, 40% Cause Downtime
item.description:
Headline: SANS Report: OT/ICS Cyber Incidents Rising, 40% Cause Downtime

Summary:
A new report from the SANS Institute highlights a dangerous trend in the security of Operational Technology (OT) and Industrial Control Systems (ICS). The '2025 State of ICS/OT Security Report' found that over 21% of organizations experienced a cyber incident in their OT environment in the past year. Of those, 40.3% suffered operational downtime. Ransomware was a primary cause, responsible for 37.9% of incidents, with unauthorized external connections being the top initial access vector. The report also points to a significant 'resilience gap,' with recovery times often exceeding one month.

Severity: Informational

Categories: Industrial Control Systems, Threat Intelligence, Ransomware

Article Type: Report

Reading Time: 5 minutes

Meta Description: The 2025 SANS State of ICS/OT Security Report finds that over 21% of organizations faced an OT cyber incident, with 40% suffering downtime, largely driven by ransomware and insecure remote access.

Article Slug: sans-report-shows-rising-ot-ics-cyber-incidents-driven-by-ransomware

Published Date: Fri, 21 Nov 2025 00:00:00 GMT

Created Date: Fri, 21 Nov 2025 15:00:00 GMT

Updated Date: Fri, 21 Nov 2025 15:00:00 GMT

Read Full Article →

item.title: NEW: Global Coalition Targets 'Bulletproof' Hosting Services Fueling Cybercrime
item.description:
Headline: Global Coalition Targets 'Bulletproof' Hosting Services Fueling Cybercrime

Summary:
An international coalition of cybersecurity agencies, including the NSA, CISA, and the FBI, has launched a coordinated effort to combat 'bulletproof' hosting (BPH) providers. These services knowingly lease infrastructure to cybercriminals for activities like ransomware and phishing. A new joint advisory urges Internet Service Providers (ISPs) and network defenders to adopt strategies to identify, block, and report these malicious hosts. The guidance focuses on a nuanced approach, including creating high-confidence blocklists and improving 'know your customer' processes, to disrupt the foundational infrastructure of cybercrime.

Severity: Informational

Categories: Policy and Compliance, Threat Intelligence, Regulatory

Article Type: Advisory

Reading Time: 4 minutes

Meta Description: A global coalition of agencies including the NSA, CISA, and FBI have released joint guidance to help ISPs and network defenders identify and dismantle criminal 'bulletproof' hosting (BPH) services.

Article Slug: global-agencies-launch-effort-against-bulletproof-hosting-providers

Published Date: Fri, 21 Nov 2025 00:00:00 GMT

Created Date: Fri, 21 Nov 2025 15:00:00 GMT

Updated Date: Fri, 21 Nov 2025 15:00:00 GMT

Read Full Article →

item.title: NEW: New 'Bactor' Ransomware Strain Discovered with Double-Extortion Tactics
item.description:
Headline: New 'Bactor' Ransomware Strain Discovered with Double-Extortion Tactics

Summary:
A new ransomware variant named 'Bactor' has been identified by security researchers. Targeting Windows systems, Bactor employs double-extortion tactics, encrypting files and threatening to leak exfiltrated data if a ransom is not paid within a 48-hour deadline. The malware actively attempts to hinder recovery by executing commands to delete Volume Shadow Copies, removing built-in Windows backups. After encryption, files are appended with the '.bactor' extension, and a ransom note named '#HowToRecover.txt' is dropped on the victim's system.

Severity: Medium

Categories: Ransomware, Malware

Article Type: NewsArticle

Reading Time: 4 minutes

Meta Description: Security researchers have identified a new ransomware strain called Bactor that targets Windows systems, employs double-extortion tactics, and deletes Volume Shadow Copies to hinder recovery.

Article Slug: new-bactor-ransomware-emerges-with-double-extortion-tactics

Published Date: Fri, 21 Nov 2025 00:00:00 GMT

Created Date: Fri, 21 Nov 2025 15:00:00 GMT

Updated Date: Fri, 21 Nov 2025 15:00:00 GMT

Read Full Article →

item.title: NEW: UK Proposes Major Cybersecurity Bill to Regulate MSPs and Data Centres
item.description:
Headline: UK Proposes Major Cybersecurity Bill to Regulate MSPs and Data Centres

Summary:
The UK government has introduced the Cyber Security and Resilience Bill, a significant legislative reform aimed at strengthening the nation's cyber defenses. The bill will expand the scope of the existing Network and Information Systems (NIS) Regulations to include managed service providers (MSPs) and data centre operators for the first time. It also proposes a stricter, two-tier penalty system with fines up to £17 million or 4% of global turnover, and mandates faster incident reporting, bringing the UK's rules more in line with the EU's NIS2 Directive.

Severity: Informational

Categories: Regulatory, Policy and Compliance

Article Type: NewsArticle

Reading Time: 4 minutes

Meta Description: The UK government has introduced the Cyber Security and Resilience Bill to expand and strengthen the NIS Regulations, bringing Managed Service Providers (MSPs) and data centres into scope and introducing larger fines.

Article Slug: uk-introduces-bill-to-expand-cybersecurity-regulations-to-msps

Published Date: Fri, 21 Nov 2025 00:00:00 GMT

Created Date: Fri, 21 Nov 2025 15:00:00 GMT

Updated Date: Fri, 21 Nov 2025 15:00:00 GMT

Read Full Article →

item.title: NEW: Microsoft Patches Actively Exploited Windows Kernel Zero-Day Flaw
item.description:
Headline: Microsoft Patches Actively Exploited Windows Kernel Zero-Day Flaw

Summary:
Microsoft's November 2025 Patch Tuesday update addresses 63 vulnerabilities, including a critical zero-day flaw in the Windows Kernel, CVE-2025-62215, that is being actively exploited. The vulnerability is an elevation of privilege bug with a CVSS score of 7.0. A local attacker who has already gained initial access can exploit a race condition to execute code with full SYSTEM-level privileges. Due to its active exploitation, Microsoft urges all users to apply the November security updates immediately.

Severity: Critical

Categories: Vulnerability, Patch Management

Article Type: NewsArticle

Reading Time: 5 minutes

Meta Description: Microsoft's November 2025 Patch Tuesday fixes an actively exploited zero-day vulnerability, CVE-2025-62215, in the Windows Kernel. The flaw allows for local privilege escalation to SYSTEM.

Article Slug: microsoft-patches-actively-exploited-windows-kernel-zero-day-cve-2025-62215

Published Date: Fri, 21 Nov 2025 00:00:00 GMT

Created Date: Fri, 21 Nov 2025 15:00:00 GMT

Updated Date: Fri, 21 Nov 2025 15:00:00 GMT

Read Full Article →

item.title: NEW: WEL Companies Investigated for Data Breach Affecting 122,960 People
item.description:
Headline: WEL Companies Investigated for Data Breach Affecting 122,960 People

Summary:
The law firm Schubert Jonckheer & Kolbe LLP is investigating transportation and logistics firm WEL Companies, Inc., following a data breach that compromised the sensitive personal information of 122,960 people. The breach, which exposed names, Social Security numbers, and driver's license numbers, was first detected in January 2025. However, the company only began notifying victims in November 2025, a delay of nearly ten months that could lead to legal action for violating data breach notification laws.

Severity: High

Categories: Data Breach, Policy and Compliance

Article Type: NewsArticle

Reading Time: 4 minutes

Meta Description: Logistics firm WEL Companies is being investigated for a data breach that exposed the Social Security numbers and other PII of 122,960 people, following a 10-month delay in notifying victims.

Article Slug: wel-companies-investigated-for-data-breach-affecting-122960-people

Published Date: Fri, 21 Nov 2025 00:00:00 GMT

Created Date: Fri, 21 Nov 2025 15:00:00 GMT

Updated Date: Fri, 21 Nov 2025 15:00:00 GMT

Read Full Article →

item.title: UPDATE: Patch Now: Microsoft Fixes Actively Exploited Windows Kernel Zero-Day
item.description:
Headline: Patch Now: Microsoft Fixes Actively Exploited Windows Kernel Zero-Day

Summary:
As part of its November 2025 Patch Tuesday release, Microsoft has addressed 63 security vulnerabilities, including a high-severity zero-day flaw in the Windows Kernel (CVE-2025-62215) that is confirmed to be under active exploitation. The vulnerability is a local privilege escalation (LPE) bug with a CVSS score of 7.0, allowing an attacker who has already gained initial access to a system to elevate their privileges to SYSTEM level. Such flaws are critical components in post-exploitation attack chains, enabling threat actors to take full control of a compromised machine. The update also fixes 16 remote code execution (RCE) vulnerabilities and numerous other flaws across the Microsoft product suite. Immediate patching is strongly recommended for all Windows users.

Severity: Critical

Categories: Vulnerability, Patch Management, Threat Intelligence

Article Type: Advisory

Reading Time: 5 minutes

Meta Description: Microsoft's November 2025 Patch Tuesday fixes 63 vulnerabilities, including CVE-2025-62215, a Windows Kernel zero-day that is actively exploited for privilege escalation. Details on the flaw and mitigation.

Article Slug: microsoft-patches-actively-exploited-windows-kernel-zero-day-cve-2025-62215-in-november-patch-tuesday

Published Date: Thu, 20 Nov 2025 00:00:00 GMT

Created Date: Thu, 20 Nov 2025 15:00:00 GMT

Updated Date: Fri, 21 Nov 2025 10:00:00 GMT

Update Count: 1

Update History: 1 update recorded

Read Full Article →

item.title: NEW: URGENT: CISA Orders 7-Day Patch for Actively Exploited FortiWeb Zero-Day
item.description:
Headline: URGENT: CISA Orders 7-Day Patch for Actively Exploited FortiWeb Zero-Day

Summary:
Fortinet has disclosed a critical OS command injection zero-day vulnerability, CVE-2025-58034, in its FortiWeb Web Application Firewall (WAF) that is being actively exploited in the wild. The flaw allows an authenticated attacker to execute arbitrary commands on the underlying system. In response to observed attacks, the U.S. Cybersecurity and Infrastructure Security Agency (CISA) has added the vulnerability to its Known Exploited Vulnerabilities (KEV) catalog and issued an emergency directive mandating federal agencies apply patches within an accelerated seven-day window, by November 25, 2025. Researchers have detected approximately 2,000 attacks leveraging the flaw and warn it could potentially be chained with a recently disclosed authentication bypass vulnerability (CVE-2025-64446) to achieve unauthenticated remote code execution.

Severity: Critical

Categories: Vulnerability, Patch Management, Cyberattack

Article Type: Advisory

Reading Time: 5 minutes

Meta Description: Fortinet discloses and CISA mandates urgent patching for CVE-2025-58034, a critical OS command injection zero-day in FortiWeb WAFs that is under active exploitation. Learn about the risks and mitigation steps.

Article Slug: cisa-mandates-7-day-patch-for-actively-exploited-fortinet-fortiweb-zero-day-cve-2025-58034

Published Date: Thu, 20 Nov 2025 00:00:00 GMT

Created Date: Thu, 20 Nov 2025 15:00:00 GMT

Updated Date: Thu, 20 Nov 2025 15:00:00 GMT

Read Full Article →

item.title: NEW: Google Chrome Zero-Day Exploited in Wild, CISA Mandates Urgent Patch
item.description:
Headline: Google Chrome Zero-Day Exploited in Wild, CISA Mandates Urgent Patch

Summary:
Google has patched a high-severity zero-day vulnerability in its Chrome web browser, CVE-2025-13223, which is being actively exploited in the wild. The flaw is a type confusion error in the V8 JavaScript engine that can be leveraged by an attacker for remote code execution (RCE) simply by luring a victim to a malicious website. Following Google's confirmation of in-the-wild exploitation, the U.S. Cybersecurity and Infrastructure Security Agency (CISA) promptly added the vulnerability to its Known Exploited Vulnerabilities (KEV) catalog, mandating that federal agencies apply the update by December 10, 2025. The vulnerability affects Chrome on all major desktop platforms (Windows, macOS, and Linux) and other Chromium-based browsers.

Severity: Critical

Categories: Vulnerability, Cyberattack, Patch Management

Article Type: Advisory

Reading Time: 5 minutes

Meta Description: CISA warns of an actively exploited Google Chrome zero-day vulnerability, CVE-2025-13223, a type confusion flaw in the V8 engine allowing for remote code execution. Update to version 131.0.6778.72 or later immediately.

Article Slug: cisa-warns-of-actively-exploited-google-chrome-zero-day-cve-2025-13223

Published Date: Thu, 20 Nov 2025 00:00:00 GMT

Created Date: Thu, 20 Nov 2025 15:00:00 GMT

Updated Date: Thu, 20 Nov 2025 15:00:00 GMT

Read Full Article →

item.title: NEW: Sinobi Ransomware Strikes US Manufacturer and Indian Tech Firm
item.description:
Headline: Sinobi Ransomware Strikes US Manufacturer and Indian Tech Firm

Summary:
The 'sinobi' ransomware group has claimed responsibility for two recent cyberattacks targeting organizations in the United States and India. The victims are Croft, a U.S.-based window and door manufacturer, and CHANGEPOND, an enterprise software company headquartered in Chennai, India. Both breaches were discovered on November 19, 2025, occurring within minutes of each other. These incidents underscore the global reach and indiscriminate targeting of ransomware operators, affecting diverse sectors including manufacturing and technology. The attacks highlight the persistent threat posed by ransomware and the importance of robust cybersecurity defenses.

Severity: High

Categories: Ransomware, Threat Actor, Cyberattack

Article Type: NewsArticle

Reading Time: 4 minutes

Meta Description: The 'sinobi' ransomware group has claimed responsibility for cyberattacks on US manufacturer Croft and Indian software company CHANGEPOND, demonstrating a global, cross-industry threat.

Article Slug: sinobi-ransomware-group-attacks-us-manufacturer-croft-and-indian-tech-firm-changepond

Published Date: Thu, 20 Nov 2025 00:00:00 GMT

Created Date: Thu, 20 Nov 2025 15:00:00 GMT

Updated Date: Thu, 20 Nov 2025 15:00:00 GMT

Read Full Article →

item.title: NEW: PA Attorney General Confirms Massive Data Breach by Inc Ransom
item.description:
Headline: PA Attorney General Confirms Massive Data Breach by Inc Ransom

Summary:
The Pennsylvania Office of the Attorney General (OAG) has officially confirmed it was the victim of a significant ransomware attack orchestrated by the 'Inc Ransom' group. The attack, which occurred in August 2025, disrupted the agency's operations for three weeks. The threat actors claim to have exfiltrated 5.7 terabytes of highly sensitive data, including Social Security numbers, medical details, and investigative files. The initial access vector is believed to be the exploitation of the 'CitrixBleed2' vulnerability (CVE-2025-5777) on the agency's Citrix NetScaler appliances. The FBI is now investigating the incident, and the OAG is in the process of notifying affected individuals.

Severity: Critical

Categories: Data Breach, Ransomware, Vulnerability

Article Type: NewsArticle

Reading Time: 5 minutes

Meta Description: The Pennsylvania Office of the Attorney General confirms it was hit by the Inc Ransom group, who exploited CVE-2025-5777 (CitrixBleed2) to steal 5.7 TB of sensitive data and disrupt operations for weeks.

Article Slug: pennsylvania-attorney-general-confirms-major-data-breach-by-inc-ransom-group

Published Date: Thu, 20 Nov 2025 00:00:00 GMT

Created Date: Thu, 20 Nov 2025 15:00:00 GMT

Updated Date: Thu, 20 Nov 2025 15:00:00 GMT

Read Full Article →

item.title: NEW: CISA and Partners Release Guide to Combat Bulletproof Hosting
item.description:
Headline: CISA and Partners Release Guide to Combat Bulletproof Hosting

Summary:
The U.S. Cybersecurity and Infrastructure Security Agency (CISA), along with the FBI, NSA, and international partners, has published a comprehensive guide to help network defenders and Internet Service Providers (ISPs) combat the threat of bulletproof hosting (BPH) providers. These services knowingly lease infrastructure to cybercriminals for a wide range of malicious activities, including ransomware, phishing, and malware distribution. The guide, 'Bulletproof Defense,' provides actionable recommendations for filtering malicious traffic, enhancing network monitoring, and improving intelligence sharing to disrupt the criminal ecosystem that relies on BPH for anonymity and resilience.

Severity: Informational

Categories: Policy and Compliance, Threat Intelligence, Security Operations

Article Type: Advisory

Reading Time: 4 minutes

Meta Description: CISA, in partnership with the FBI and NSA, has published a new guide to help organizations mitigate risks from bulletproof hosting (BPH) providers that support cybercrime.

Article Slug: cisa-and-fbi-release-guide-to-combat-malicious-bulletproof-hosting-providers

Published Date: Thu, 20 Nov 2025 00:00:00 GMT

Created Date: Thu, 20 Nov 2025 15:00:00 GMT

Updated Date: Thu, 20 Nov 2025 15:00:00 GMT

Read Full Article →

item.title: NEW: AI-Driven Attacks Explode: Malware Emails Spike 131%, Report Finds
item.description:
Headline: AI-Driven Attacks Explode: Malware Emails Spike 131%, Report Finds

Summary:
A new cybersecurity report from Hornetsecurity highlights a dramatic increase in AI-powered cyberattacks throughout 2025. The analysis of over 72 billion emails revealed that the volume of malware-laden emails grew by 131% year-over-year, while phishing and scam attempts also rose significantly. The report attributes this surge to threat actors' adoption of generative AI, which enables the creation of highly convincing and sophisticated malicious content at scale. In response, 77% of CISOs now view AI-generated phishing as a major threat, and 68% of organizations have invested in AI-powered defenses, signaling a new 'arms race' in cybersecurity.

Severity: Medium

Categories: Threat Intelligence, Phishing, Malware

Article Type: Report

Reading Time: 4 minutes

Meta Description: A 2025 Hornetsecurity report finds that AI-driven cyberattacks are surging, with malware-laden emails increasing by 131% as threat actors weaponize generative AI for more sophisticated phishing campaigns.

Article Slug: ai-powered-cyberattacks-surge-malware-emails-up-131-percent-report

Published Date: Thu, 20 Nov 2025 00:00:00 GMT

Created Date: Thu, 20 Nov 2025 15:00:00 GMT

Updated Date: Thu, 20 Nov 2025 15:00:00 GMT

Read Full Article →

item.title: NEW: CISA Issues 6 New ICS Advisories for Schneider Electric, Shelly, METZ CONNECT
item.description:
Headline: CISA Issues 6 New ICS Advisories for Schneider Electric, Shelly, METZ CONNECT

Summary:
On November 19, 2025, the U.S. Cybersecurity and Infrastructure Security Agency (CISA) released six new Industrial Control Systems (ICS) advisories, highlighting multiple vulnerabilities in products from Schneider Electric, Shelly, and METZ CONNECT. The alerts affect a range of operational technology (OT) products, including SCADA systems and power monitoring devices. Four of the advisories are for Schneider Electric products like EcoStruxure and PowerChute. CISA urges administrators in critical infrastructure and manufacturing sectors to review the advisories and apply the recommended mitigations to prevent potential exploitation.

Severity: Medium

Categories: Industrial Control Systems, Vulnerability, Patch Management

Article Type: Advisory

Reading Time: 4 minutes

Meta Description: CISA has released six new Industrial Control Systems (ICS) advisories detailing vulnerabilities in products from Schneider Electric, Shelly, and METZ CONNECT. Critical infrastructure operators should review and mitigate.

Article Slug: cisa-publishes-six-new-advisories-for-industrial-control-systems-ics

Published Date: Thu, 20 Nov 2025 00:00:00 GMT

Created Date: Thu, 20 Nov 2025 15:00:00 GMT

Updated Date: Thu, 20 Nov 2025 15:00:00 GMT

Read Full Article →

item.title: NEW: CISA Releases "Be Air Aware" Guides to Combat Drone Threats
item.description:
Headline: CISA Releases "Be Air Aware" Guides to Combat Drone Threats

Summary:
As part of Critical Infrastructure Security and Resilience Month, the U.S. Cybersecurity and Infrastructure Security Agency (CISA) has released three new guides under its "Be Air Aware™" campaign. These resources are designed to help critical infrastructure owners and operators understand, assess, and mitigate the growing security risks posed by Unmanned Aircraft Systems (UAS), or drones. The guides provide actionable information on detecting suspicious drone activity, implementing detection technologies, and safely handling downed aircraft, aiming to integrate aerial threat considerations into existing security plans.

Severity: Informational

Categories: Policy and Compliance, Industrial Control Systems, Security Operations

Article Type: Advisory

Reading Time: 4 minutes

Meta Description: CISA's new 'Be Air Aware' campaign provides three new guides to help critical infrastructure owners and operators defend against the growing security threats posed by drones (UAS).

Article Slug: cisa-launches-be-air-aware-guides-to-defend-critical-infrastructure-from-drone-threats

Published Date: Thu, 20 Nov 2025 00:00:00 GMT

Created Date: Thu, 20 Nov 2025 15:00:00 GMT

Updated Date: Thu, 20 Nov 2025 15:00:00 GMT

Read Full Article →

item.title: NEW: New 'Nova Stealer' Malware Targets macOS Crypto Wallets
item.description:
Headline: New 'Nova Stealer' Malware Targets macOS Crypto Wallets

Summary:
A new information-stealing malware, dubbed 'Nova Stealer,' has been discovered actively targeting Apple macOS users. The malware's primary goal is the exfiltration of sensitive data, with a specific focus on cryptocurrency wallets. Nova Stealer operates as a trojan, infecting systems by replacing legitimate, installed applications with malicious versions. When a user launches the compromised application, the malware activates in the background to search for and steal wallet files and other valuable information. This discovery underscores the increasing trend of threat actors developing malware for the macOS platform, challenging the perception of it being inherently more secure than Windows.

Severity: High

Categories: Malware, Threat Intelligence, Mobile Security

Article Type: NewsArticle

Reading Time: 4 minutes

Meta Description: Security researchers have identified 'Nova Stealer,' a new information-stealing malware that targets macOS users by trojanizing legitimate applications to steal cryptocurrency wallets and data.

Article Slug: new-nova-stealer-malware-targets-macos-users-for-cryptocurrency-wallets

Published Date: Thu, 20 Nov 2025 00:00:00 GMT

Created Date: Thu, 20 Nov 2025 15:00:00 GMT

Updated Date: Thu, 20 Nov 2025 15:00:00 GMT

Read Full Article →
